body.div:
Chapter 23
When I had attained the age of
seventeen my fatherparents resolved that
I should go to
become a student at the university of In
golstadt. I had hitherto attended the
schools of Geneva, but my father thought
it necessary for the completion of my
education that that I should be
made acquainted with other customs besidesthan
those of my native country. My depar
ture was therefore fixed for at an
early ^date. But before the day resolved
upon could arrive the first mis
fortune of my life occurred: as if an
omen as it were of my future miseryif
I should prosecute my journey.
>Elizabeth had caught the scar
let fever but
her illness was
not severe and she quickly recovered.
During her confinement mady ^ made manyar
guments had been urged to persuade
my mother not ato refrain from to attend upon
her. She had yielded the to theseto our entreaties, but
when she ha heard that her
favourite was recovering, she wcould
no longer debar herself from her
society, and entered her sick cham
ber long before
it was safethe danger of infection was past. The
consequences of this imprudence were
fatal: on the third day my mother
sickened. Her fever was verymalig
nant, tr and the looks of her atten
dants prognosticated the wort worst
evil. On her death bed the forti
tude and benignity di of my motherthis admirable woman
did not desert her. She joined the
hands of Elizabeth and myself. "My
"children said she it was on your
"union that my firmest hopes of
"future happiness were placed. It
"will now be the consolation of
"your fathor father.alone Elizabeth, my
"love, supply my place to the other
"your young cons
cousins. Alas! I
"almost regret beingthan I am taken from you,
"h and happy and beloved, as I am
"is it not hard to quit you all? But
"these are not thoughts befitting me
"I ^will endeavour to resign myself to cheerfully to
"death and will indulge a hope my
"beloved creatures of meeting you
"in another world."
She died calmly and her features
expressed lov affection even in death.
I need not describe the feelings of those
whose dearest ties are rent by that
most irreperable evil; the bla void
that every where presents itself to
their ^ mindsthe soul and the despair that
is exhibited on the countenance.
It is so long before the mind can
persuade itself that she, whom
they saw every day, and whose very
existence appeared a part of theirs,
can have departed for ever: Tthat
the brightness of a loved eye can have
fadedbeen extinguished, and the sound of a voice never
so familiar and dear to the ear
can be hushed, never more to be
heard. These are the reflections of the
first days. But when the lapse of
time proves the reality of the evil
then the true despairbitterness of grief commences,
Then the survivors dare not turn
ButYet, from whom who has not had some dear
connection rent away by that rude hand
rent away some
dear connection,
and why needshould I describe a sorrow
which all have felt, and must
feel? But tThe time at length arrives
when grief is rather an indulgence
a than a necessity and the smile
that plays on the lips, although
it is deemed sacriledge, is not Ba
nished.– My mother was gonelosthad be en
taken ^ awaywas dead but we had still
duties which we ought to perform
we must continue our course with
the rest & bless God if nothing else ^ worsehap
pens.
and the idleness generated by grief would
become a bad habit if further indulged
and learn
to think our
selvesfortu
nate, if no
more whilst
one remains
whom the
spoiler has
not seized.
My journey to Ingolstadt which had
been deferred by these events was now
again determined upon, and all that
I could obtained from my father wasa
respite of some weeks. This time
was spent sadly. My mothers death
and my speedy departure depressed
our spirits but Elizabeth endeavour
ed to spr renew the spirit cast aa gleamrenew the spirit of cheer
fullness in our little society. Since
the death of her aunt her mind
had acquired new
firmess
firmness and
vigour. She determined to fulfil her
duties with the greatest exactitude
and
hershe felt that the most imperious duty wasof
to
rendering her uncle and cousins hap
py.
had devolved
on her. She consoled me, amused her uncle,
and
instructed my brothers and I never
beheld her so enchanting as at this
time when she sar sacrifised every
minute of her time to others ^wascontinual
ly endeavouring to contribute to the
happiness of others entirely forgetful
of
hels herself.
The day of my departure at lenghth
arrived – I had taken leave of all
my friends excepting Clerval, who spent
the last evening with us. He bitterly la
mented that he was
not ableunable to
accompany me But his father
could not
bearbe persuaded to part with him
besides as he intendedinghim tothat he shouldbe
come a partner with him in
his business, and he said he did not
and
in
compliance
with his favou
rite theory,
that
the
learning
was superflous
in the com
merce of ordi
nary life.
see
^of what use learning was ^ could be to a
merchant.
Henry had a refined mind
and a
he
did not wishhad no desire to be idle
and was well pleased to become the
partnerof
his father's ^partnerbut he believed
that a man might be a very good
trader and yet
haveposess a cultivated
mind.understanding.
We sate late listening to his com
plaints, and
I
making many little
arrangements for the future.
and tThe
next morning early I departed. Tears
gushed from the eyes of Elizabeth
they proceeded partly from sorrow
at my departure, and partly because
she reflected that the same journey
was to have taken place three
months before when a mothers
blessing would have accompanied me
I threw myself into the chaise
that was to convey me away and in
dulged in the most melancholy reflec
tions. I who had ever been surrounded
by amiable companions, continually
engaged in ed endeavouring to give
mutual pleasure; I was now alone.
In the university wi whither I was
going I must form my own friends
and be my own introduction .protector. My
life had hitherto been remarkably retired
and domestic and this had given me
an invincible repugnance to new faces
countenances. I loved my brothers Eliza
beth and Clerval these were "old
familiar faces" but I believed my
self totally unfitted for the compa
ny of strangers. Such were my reflec
tions as I commenced my journey But
as I proceeded my spirits and hopes
rose. I ardently desired knowledge
and I
I had often when at home
thought howit hard it was to remain
during my youth cooped up in one place all my
life and had longed to enter into the
worth world and take my place
with
station among other human beings. And
now my desires were cop complyed
with & it would ^indeedhavebe indeed been folly to
repent.
I had plenty ofsufficient leisure for these
and many other reflections during
my journey to Ingolstadt which was
long and fatiguing – at length the
steeples of the town met my eyes. I
alighted and was conducted to my
solitary apartment to spend the
evening as I pleased.
Chap. 4
The next morning I delivered my
letters of introduction and paid a
visit to some of the principal
professors. and among others to M. K —
KrempeKrempe
Professor of & Lecturer upon Natural
philosophy. He received me with
politeness, and asked me several
questions concerning my progress
in the sciences different branches
of science appertaining to natural
philosophy. I mentioned, it is true
with fear and trembling, the only
authors I had ^ever read upon those
subjects. The professor stared. I said
that I did not mention these
"Have you really" said" he "spent
"your time in studying such
"nonsence?" I replied in the affir
mative.
"Every minute"– continued M. K —
Krempe
with warmth," every instant that
"you have wasted upon those
"books is utterly and entirely lost.
"You have burdened your bur
"memor memory with exploded
"systems and useless names. Good
"God where must youin what desart land have you
"lived where no one was kind
"enough to enfor inform you
"that these fancies which ^you have
"so greedily imbibed are at le a
"thousand years old and as musty as
"your they are ancient. I little expected
"in this enlightened and scientific age
"to find a disciple of Albertus Mag
"nus and Paracelsus. My dear sir
"you must begin your studies entire
ly anew." So saying he stesspped aside, and
wh wrote down a list of several
books u upon natural philosophy
which he desired me to procure
and dismissed me after mentioning
that he intended to commen in
the beginning of the next week
he intended to commence a course
of lectures upon natural philosophy X
X in its general relations;
and that M. W.— ^aldham a fellow professor
would lecture upon chemistry
the alternate days which he missed.
I returned home not dissapointed
for I had long considered the au
thors useless which the professor
had so strongly reprobated – but I
did not feel very much enclined
to bu
study those books which at
his
recon recommondation I had
procured. M. K—rempe was a little squat
man with a gruff voice and repul
sive countenance and the teacher
did not prepossess me in favour
of his science .doctrine.
But when the ne Be
